title: How do I choose a roller blind?

fields.body:
When choosing a roller blind in the Australian context, there are a few factors to consider.

1. Material: Roller blinds come in various materials such as blockout, sunscreen, and light-filtering.

- Blockout blinds offer maximum privacy, thermal insulation and light control.
- Sunscreen blinds allow natural light to filter through, daytime privacy and the ability to see the view outside.
- Light-filtering blinds provide protection against harsh Australian UV rays, reduce sun glare, and filter light, offering complete daytime and limited nighttime privacy.

When choosing material, consider your requirements and preferences.

2. Size and Fit: Measure your window accurately to ensure the roller blind fits appropriately. Consider whether you want a Recess Fit ("inside mount"/ within the window frame) or a Face Fit ("outside mount " /covering the entire window frame). Also, consider any obstructions like handles or window cranks, tiles, skirting boards, etc., that may affect the fit.

3. Style and Design: Roller blinds come in various colours, patterns, and textures. Choose a style that complements your decor and enhances the room's aesthetic. Consider the colour scheme and how the back fabric of the blinds will look from the outside for the best appeal, furniture, and overall ambience when selecting. For more advice, we recommend reading this guide on How to Choose Fabrics and Colours for Roller Blinds.

4. Operation: Decide on the type of operation you prefer. Roller blinds can be operated manually with a chain, cord, or motorised for convenience. Motorised blinds allow for remote control or integration with smart home systems.

5. Budget: Determine your budget range and explore options within that range. Roller blinds can vary in price depending on the material, size, and additional features. Consider the long-term durability and quality of the blinds when making your decision.

twitter.title: How do I choose a roller blind?

facebook.title: How do I choose a roller blind?

title: What roller blinds can see out but not in?

fields.body:
Sunscreen Roller Blinds offer daytime privacy while still providing a view outside. However, this changes at night when the darkness outside contrasts with indoor lighting, potentially allowing outsiders to see into the home through the blinds.

Light Filtering Roller Blinds are similar to bathroom window frosting. They allow filtered light into the room but prevent visibility through the fabric to the outside view. They also obstruct the view into the home from outside, except at night when silhouettes may be visible if there is light inside and darkness outside.

For total privacy, we recommend choosing Blockout Roller Blinds. These blinds ensure complete privacy day and night while effectively blocking out unwanted light.

In that case, we recommend having the block out fabric as close to the window opening back rolling and having the front fabric as sunscreen or light filtering rolling forward. title: What's the difference between regular double brackets vs slimline double brackets?

fields.body:
The regular double roller bracket dimension is 120mm by 120mm, requiring a window recess depth of at least 150mm. Great for windows with deep reveals.

Slimline double roller blinds have an ultra-slim profile because the two blinds are stacked vertically to save space. The bracket dimensions are 85mm by 148mm and require at least 120mm of window recess depth. Used for windows with shallow reveals (at least 120mm). They can be installed discreetly inside recesses with at least 120mm depth and minimal obstructions or face fitted onto architraves or walls.

title: How do roller blinds differ from double roller blinds ?

fields.body:
Single Roller Blinds:

Construction: Traditional roller blinds are made of a single layer of fabric or material.

Light Control: They either block out light completely with blackout materials or filter it partially with translucent fabrics.

Operation: These blinds usually operate with a cord or chain, and some models offer motorised options.

Design Variety: They come in a wide range of colours, patterns, and materials, suitable for various interior designs.

Best For: Those who prefer simplicity and a clean, minimalistic look.

Double Roller Blinds:

Construction: Double roller blinds feature two layers of fabric, each of which can be operated Independently.

Enhanced Light Control: With a combination of light filtering or sunscreen fabric and blockout fabric, these blinds offer more versatility in controlling light and privacy day & night.

Operation: They typically have two chains for separate operations of each layer, and motorised options are also available.

Design Flexibility: These blinds are ideal for those who need a combination of light filtering during the day and complete blockout at times.


Best For: Homeowners looking for a functional yet stylish window treatment that offers more control over light and privacy.

title: What is 2-pass vs. 3-pass blockout curtains?

fields.body:
2-pass Blockout Curtains: These have two layers. The first layer is a coloured curtain fabric, and the second is a black foam coating on the back. This black layer is designed to block out light and improve insulation.

3-pass Blockout Curtains: These include an additional layer, making three total. There's the front decorative fabric, a black foam layer in the middle for light absorption, and a white foam layer on the back. This extra layer enhances the blackout properties, increases thermal insulation, and often improves the curtain's overall appearance from outside the window.

title: What’s the difference between a “cord and cleat” control  and a “chain drive”?

fields.body:
There are 4 ways you can control the way your roman blinds open and close. Just select your preferred method of control when you’re customising your roman blind.

  1. Cord and cleat: This is the most common and traditional way of controlling roman blinds. To raise the blinds, simply pull the cord and once the blinds are at your preferred height you wind the cord around a cleat (or hook) on the window frame.
  2. Cord lock: this is similar to a cord and cleat, except instead of winding the cord around the cleat just tug the cord to the side to lock it. This cord lock is also seen in many Venetian blinds.
  3. Chain drive: this is the type of control you might be used to seeing on roller blinds. It’s a connected length of chain that you pull to either raise or lower the blinds.
  4. Motorisation: automate your life and enjoy hands-free living with motorised roman blinds. Roman blinds need to be at least 710mm wide to be fitted with a motor. Find out more about motorised blinds.

If you’re installing multiple roman blinds for the same room, we recommend selecting “uniform” batten alignment when ordering. This will create a uniform look and ensure the panels line up (assuming the tops of your windows are all the same height).

If you don’t select this, we’ll choose the best location for each batten depending on the size of your window – but even if your windows are all the same size, this could vary slightly.

title: Why do you offer free samples?

There are 2 main reasons we love providing free samples to our customers.

First, the absolute best place to choose fabrics for your home is in your home. The brightness, intensity, and temperature of light, as well as surrounding colours, can completely change the look of a fabric – so there’s no point looking at fabrics anywhere else.

This leads us to the second reason: if the best place to look at fabrics is in your home, why would we waste money on expensive showrooms. By offering free samples we get to keep prices low and pass the savings on to you, and you get can be completely confident in your decisions.

title: Can you see through sheer window curtains?

fields.body:
During the day, sheer curtains allow you to see outside while also blocking people outside from looking in.

This is because with sheer curtains you can only see from the darker side into the brighter side. This does mean that if it’s night time and the lights are on inside then it’s possible to see inside, so if your curtains are in a room that faces onto a street or public areas, we recommend pairing with a blockout roller blind or a luxurious double curtain which pairs a sheer curtain and blockout curtain.

title: My blind won't fit into the brackets, it's too tight.

fields.body:
Inside the frame (recess fit) and Outside the frame (face fit)
If your blind doesn't fit because the brackets are too close together, call us and we'll talk you through options to get your blinds fitting perfectly.

Outside a frameless window (face fit frameless window)
If your blind doesn't fit, you can simply move the brackets further apart.

Remove your brackets
If you have a pelmet, take it down before you start.

At the top of your blind, on the pin end side, rotate the clear plastic cog anti-clockwise. This will retract the pin away from the bracket, just enough for you to remove that side of the blind completely. Then take the opposite side of the blind out of the bracket.

Now you can use your cordless drill with the Phillips head drill bit to remove the screws, using the drill's reverse function. Then take down your brackets.

Take the right measurement
Lay your blind on the floor, then take your tape measure and measure the exact width of your roller blind, from left to right (see note) and write it down. This is the correct width between your two brackets.

Mark up
Now measure out the correct width between brackets, onto your wall and 70 mm above the top of your window and draw a small line at each end.

Then simply repeat from step 2 onwards of this guide to put your blind back up.

title: How do I add blinds to or remove blinds from my rooms with Google Home?

fields.body:
Head to your Google Home app home screen and tap the cog symbol next to the blind or curtain you want to add to or remove from a room.

Tap the Room option and then tap to select the room name you want to use from the list e.g. living room. The room you choose will display a tick symbol next to it. You can also remove your blind from a room by tapping the room name so the tick symbol disappears.

Tap SAVE in the top right corner and then tap the cross symbol (x) in the top left corner of your screen (iOS devices) or the back arrow in the top left corner of your screen (Android devices) to return to the app home screen.

title: Can I setup multiple blinds motors on a single channel on my Somfy remote?

fields.body:
Yes. If you are setting up a battery motor. You can setup the first motor using the setup instructions above. Once complete, you need to put the motor to sleep using the below steps:

  1. Press and hold the motor head button until the blinds briefly moves Up and Down. Release the button once complete.
  2. Briefly press the motor head button, the blind will briefly move Up and Down twice. Motor is in sleeping mode.
  3. Setup the next motor on the same channel using the steps in the above guide.
  4. The deactivate Sleeping Mode, briefly press the motor head button. The blind will move Up and Down.

title: Can I adjust the speed of my blind motor on my Somfy remote?

fields.body:
Yes. Once you've completed the setup of the motor, you can adjust the speed (either slower or faster) using the below steps:

  1. Move the blind to 50% open.
  2. Once stopped, press and hold Up, My & Down buttons together until the blind jogs. The blind will start moving Up and Down automatically in cycles.
  3. To increase the speed - press and hold the UP button until the blind jogs. The speed will be increased. Repeat as needed.
  4. To decrease the speed - press and hold the DOWN button until the blind jogs. The speed will be decreased. Repeat as needed.
  5. To confirm the new speed - press and hold the MY button until the blind jogs.

title: Can I start over if I miss a step when setting up blinds on my Somfy remote?

fields.body:
Mistakes happen! No need to worry, you can easily start over if you miss a step during set up.

To erase any settings you added, press and hold the button (Altus) or pin hole (Sonesse) on your roller blind motor head for 13 seconds. Your blind will jog up and down 3 times during the reset process. Now you can start the set up again.

For wired motors, if you make a mistake part way through set up just unplug the motor, wait for 10 seconds then plug the motor back in. Now you can start the set up again.

title: My louvers are hard to rotate, or they're too loose.

fields.body:
The good news is they're easy to loosen or tighten.

First find the tension screws on your shutter panels. They're on the side opposite your hinges and have a round plastic sticker over them.

Turn the screws to tighten or loosen your louvers. You have one screw for each section of louvers (as connected by the tilt bar at the back).

title: My shutter louvers keep popping out.

fields.body: OK, let's check if your shutter frame or panels are completely vertical. If it's on a slight angle or twisted, that's enough to make the louvers pop out.
Outside the window frame (face fit) and Outside a frameless window (face fit frameless window)

Check your shutter frame
Place your spirit level on the front face of the shutter frame, to check if the frame is perfectly vertical. It might only be a small amount off, but you want it to be square. Check on both sides of the frame.

Make your shutter frame vertical
If the shutter frame isn't vertical, undrill the screws part way at either the top or the bottom (whichever is sitting deeper), using your cordless drill with a Phillips head drill bit. Undrill the side screws part way too, and gently bring the top or the bottom of the frame slightly forward. You can hold up a spirit level and check when it's vertical on each side. Check to see if your louvers stop popping out.

Tighten your screws
Tighten the screws back in using your cordless drill, keeping the frame vertical. You can also caulk where there's a gap.

If this still doesn't fix it, give us a call and we can help.
Inside the window frame (recess fit)

Check your shutter frame
Place your spirit level on the front face of the shutter frame, to check if the frame is perfectly vertical. It might only be a small amount off, but you want it to be square. Check on both sides of the frame.

Make your shutter frame vertical
If the shutter frame isn't vertical, undrill every screw in your frame, using your cordless drill with a Phillips head drill bit. Bring the top or the bottom of the frame slightly forward (whichever is sitting deeper). You can hold up a spirit level and check when it's vertical on each side. Check to see if your louvers stop popping out.

Drill your screws back in
Drill all your screws back in, keeping the frame vertical. Follow step 3 of this guide, to drill screws in the right order.

If this still doesn't fix it, give us a call and we can help.
Inside the window frame (direct mount)

Check your shutter panels
Place your spirit level on the front face of your shutter panels, to check if the panels are perfectly vertical. They might only be a small amount off, but you want them to be square.

Make your shutter panels vertical
If your shutter panels aren't vertical, undrill the screws on all your brackets, using your cordless drill with a Phillips head drill bit. Bring the top or the bottom of the panel slightly forward (whichever is sitting deeper). You can hold up a spirit level and check when the panel is vertical. Check to see if your louvers stop popping out.

If you have T posts, follow this step to make your T posts vertical.

Drill your screws back in
Drill the screws back in using your cordless drill, keeping the panel vertical.

If this still doesn't fix it, give us a call and we can help.

title: My linked roller blinds aren't lining up.

fields.body:
The easiest fix for blinds that don't line up is to roll them all the way down then back up again. Once you've done this your blinds should be lined up.

Do you have different fabrics for your linked blinds? Sometimes your blinds can get slightly out of alignment due to the different thicknesses of your fabrics.

To fix this roll your blinds all the way down until you see the bare, aluminium tubes. Grab some masking tape and add a strip of tape the whole way across the metal tube of the slower blind(s). This increases the thickness of the slow blind(s) to match the thickness of the quicker blind(s). Roll all your blinds up again and check if your blinds are lined up.

title: It's hard to roll my blind up and down, or it's making clunking noises.

fields.body: How to fix a blind chain ? We've got an easy fix for that.

Remove your roller blind
At the top of your blind, on the pin end side, rotate the clear plastic cog anti-clockwise. This will retract the pin away from the bracket, just enough for you to remove that side of the blind completely. Then take the opposite side of the blind out of the bracket.

Adjust the hood position and click your blind back in
Check that the hood over the chain is at 12 o'clock and the ACMEDA logo is at 6 o'clock.

Gently slot the chain end back into the chain drive bracket.

Then slot the pin end into the pin end bracket, until you hear a click.

Check the fit
Check that your blind rolls up and down easily and smoothly, and you're done!

title: My blind is tracking to one side.

fields.body: All you need is masking tape to fix this one.
Unroll your blind all the way down, until you see the bare aluminium tube.
Cut a 5 cm strip of masking tape and stick it onto the aluminium tube, on the side you need the blind to go to. Roll your blind back up to check if it tracks straight.

Add a couple more layers of masking tape for thickness, until the blind rolls up straight.

If this doesn't fix the problem, please contact us.

title: I want my chain on the opposite side.

fields.body: No problem, you can do it yourself.

Remove your brackets
If you have a pelmet, take it down before you start.

At the top of your blind, on the pin end side, rotate the clear plastic cog anti-clockwise. This will retract the pin away from the bracket, just enough for you to remove that side of the blind completely. Then take the opposite side of the blind out of the bracket.

Now you can use your cordless drill with the Phillips head drill bit to remove the screws, using the drill's reverse function. Then take down your brackets.

Swap the end caps
Lay your blind on a clean floor and pull out each end cap.

Swap them over, then insert them back into your blind. Remember the chain drive end needs to go on the side where you want your chain.

Put your brackets and blind back up
Then simply repeat from step 3 onwards of this guide to put your blind back up.

title: I'd like to take my whole blind down while I redecorate.

fields.body: Taking your blinds down is a cinch and there's nothing like a new lick of paint to lift your room.

Take your pelmet down
First unclip your pelmet, if you have one.

Remove your blind
Then at top of your blind, on the pin end side, just rotate the clear plastic cog anti-clockwise. This will retract the pin away from the bracket, just enough for you to remove that side of the blind completely. Then take the opposite side out of the bracket.

Now you can either redecorate with the brackets in place, or use a cordless drill with a Phillips head drill bit to remove the screws, using the drill's reverse function. Then take down your brackets.

After you've redecorated
Simply repeat from step 2 onwards of this guide to put your blind back up.

Don't forget to snap some photos and share your new look with us!
